--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> 
> I've looked into SharpNEAT's crossover algorithm and it is 
definitely 
> doing a full combine of both parent genomes, so the new genome 
will get 
> all of the fittest parent's genes plus any excess & disjoint from 
the 
> other parent. If the parents are of equal fitness then matching 
genes 
> are selected from randomly (50% chance of getting gene from either 
> parent), and ALL of the excess and disjoint genes from both 
parents are 
> included.
> 
> So now I'm trying to sort this out by going back to Ken's NEAT 
papers 
> for an explanation on the crossover technique, but I'm having 
> difficulty. From "Competitive Coevolution through Evolutionary 
> Complexification", section 3.2, paragraph 4:
> 
> -----------------
> "Through innovation numbers, the system now knows exactly which 
genes 
> match up with which (Figure 4). Genes that do not match are either 
> /disjoint/ or /excess/, depending on whether they occur within or 
> outside the range of the other parent's innovation numbers. When 
> crossing over, the genes with the same innovation numbers are 
lined up 
> and are randomly chosen for the offspring genome. Genes that do 
not 
> match are inherited from the more fit parent, or if they are 
equally 
> fit, from both parents randomly. Disabled genes have a 25% chance 
of 
> being reenabled during crossover, allowing networks to make use of 
older 
> genes once again."
> -----------------
> 
> So I'm doing a couple of things wrong:
> 
> 1) When genes match I take the gene from the fittest parent. 
Whereas I 
> should be randomly selecting from both parents. Right? Currently I 
only 
> to this if both parent are equally fit.
> 2) I am always including *all* excess and disjoint genes from the 
least 
> fit parent.
> 
> 

Right on #1: You should be taking the matching genes from both 
parents, selecting at random.

On #2, it is true that I didn't take *any* of the excess or disjoint 
genes from the least fit parent.

> However I am not 100% sure how original NEAT works w.r.t this 
second 
> point...
> 
> "Genes that do not match are inherited from the more fit parent, 
or if 
> they are equally fit, from both parents randomly."
> 
> So just to be clear on this, this is saying that excess and 
disjoint 
> genes from the least fit parent are not used, right? and if both 
parents 
> are equal, should I take all of the excess and disjoint genes from 
both 
> parents or just some percentage of them? I think the 
term 'randomly' in

Yes this is correct: When they are equally fit you use all the 
excess and disjoint genes in the offspring.
 
> this senetence is confusing me, does it mean that I should only be 
> selecting a sub-set of the excess and disjoint genes from both 
parents, 
> or is it merely alluding to the fact that the excess and disjoint 
genes 
> are distributed acrosss the two parents, and that therefore we are 
> selecting them from whichever parent they happen to be on, but 
it's not 
> actually a random selection as such.
> 
> 
> Something about this doesn't seem right to me. It means that the 
> crossover almost always only combines weight values, not 
topolgies. e.g. 
> in my OCR experiment, if two different genomes have each 
discovered a 
> distinct beneficial input-output connection then the only way we 
can 
> combine the two genomes to get the benefit of both connections is 
if 
> they happen to have the same fitness, right?
> 

Yes right, there is a potential missed opportunity.

> If this is the case then I would have thought it would be better 
to use 
> excess and disjoint genes from the least fit parent more often, 
like 
> when the parent are unequal.
> 

I agree, actually.  You really don't want to overemphasize the 
particulars of my implementation.  It was done that way primarily to 
avoid the possibility of bloat.  And it does reduce bloat somewhat, 
but at the expense of what you say: you lose opportunities to 
combine disjoint structures.  I don't want people to feel compelled 
to follow my exact implementation decisions, since I think these 
possibilities and trade-offs certainly deserve to be explored.  
Obviously being the first to make such a system, I had to make a 
large number of specific implementation decisions with no precedent 
whatsoever, so it's not surprising in retrospect if a few could be 
done better or differently.   So absolutely feel free to follow your 
gut instinct about what would work best.

ken
